description: Borrowed from Latin complicatus, past participle of complicare (“to fold together”), from com- (“together”) + plicare (“to fold, weave, knit”); see plaid, and compare complex.

adjectives.description: complicate (comparative more complicate, superlative most complicate)

examples: How poor, how rich, how abject, how august, / How complicate, how wonderful, is Man!

verbs.description: complicate (third-person singular simple present complicates, present participle complicating, simple past and past participle complicated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make complex; to modify so as to make something intricate or difficult.
(transitive) To involve in a convoluted matter.
examples: Don't complicate yourself in issues that are beyond the scope of your understanding.
John has been complicated in the affair by new tapes that surfaced.
The DA has made every effort to complicate me in the scandal.
